dc:description:
*SHANK1* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in 2012 (Sato et al., PMID: 22503632). The authors reported a male proband with a *de novo* deletion spanning *SHANK1* and *SYT3*, and a multigenerational family with six individuals carrying a deletion of *SHANK1* and *CLEC11A*, in which the males, but not the carrier mothers, had ASD. None of these cases were awarded points in this curation because the deletions encompass other genes. Subsequently, May et al. (2021, PMID: 34113010) reported *de novo* truncating variants in *SHANK1* in six probands with a spectrum of neurodevelopmental disorders, including motor and speech delays, intellectual disability or learning disabilities, ASD, hypotonia, and seizures. At least 9 additional probands with *SHANK1* truncating variants and complex neurodevelopmental disorder, including intellectual disability, developmental delay, ASD, and epilepsy, have been reported in large cohort studies (PMIDs: 27824329, 29100083, 33057194, 34113010, 34374989, 35982160, 36980980). Seven *de novo* truncating variants (nonsense, frameshift, and splice) that have been reported in seven probands in two publications (PMIDs: 27824329, 34113010) are included in this curation. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points) has been reached. In addition to the two unaffected deletion carrier mothers mentioned above (PMID: 22503632), a *SHANK1* *de novo* truncating variant was observed in an unaffected male sibling of an ASD proband (PMID: 35982160), suggesting incomplete penetrance. The mechanism of pathogenicity is loss of function (PMID: 34113010). 

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by experimental evidence, including functional alteration, biochemical function, and animal models. *SHANK1* is a member of the SHANK gene family, which includes *SHANK1*, *SHANK2*, and *SHANK3*, and encodes scaffolding proteins that are enriched in the postsynaptic density of glutamatergic synapses. *SHANK2* and *SHANK3* are also involved in neurodevelopmental disorders associated with ASD and intellectual disability.
 
In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *SHANK1* and autosomal dominant complex neurodevelopmental disorder. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on March 20, 2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: The score is upgraded because the synaptic function of Shank1, which is shared with Shank2 and Shank3, both of which have definitive relationships to ID and ASD, provides strong evidence linking Shank1 to ID and ASD.

All three SHANK proteins (SHANK1, SHANK2 and SHANK3) encode a family of postsynaptic scaffolding proteins that are present at glutamatergic synapses in the CNS. They localize to postsynaptic density (PSD) by forming protein complex with NMDA receptor/PSD-95/GKAP1 and play a role in synaptic function. See Monteiro P et al., 2017 (PMID: 28179641) for review. Mutations in SHANK3 and SHANK2 also cause complex neurodevelopmental disorders with ID and ASD.

Shank1 promotes the maturation of dendritic spines and the enlargement of spine heads via its ability to recruit Homer1 to postsynaptic sites (figures 4 and 5).

Shank1 and Homer expression in neurons increase miniature excitatory postsynaptic currents (mEPSC) frequency in transfected neurons which enhances presynaptic function (Figure 9).
evidence.rdfs:label: SHANK1 function in dendritic spine maturation and synapse

evidence.dc:description:
Study of 2 de novo truncating variants in the penultimate exon of SHANK1 (p.Gly1105fs and p.Glu1119*) observed in affected individuals. Both variants escaped nonsense-mediated decay and resulted in stable transcripts. Truncated SHANK1 proteins transfected in cultured rat hippocampal neurons lost synaptic localization.

Truncated SHANK1 proteins completely lost binding with Homer1, a linker protein that binds to the C-terminus of SHANK1, in HEK293 cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Truncated SHANK1 lost Homer1 binding & synaptic localization

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded because the deficit in object recognition was only observed in adult heterozygous males, but not in juveniles or females. Furthermore, other studies of cognitive deficits in Shank1-deficient mice have shown inconsistent results, with reports of normal performance, deficits, or even improved performance on some tasks (Hung et al., 2008, PMID: 18272690; Silverman et al., 2011, PMID: 20868654).

Novel object recognition was assessed in juvenile and adult Shank1+/+, Shank1+/−, and Shank1−/− male and female mice.
Both female and male juvenile Shank1−/− mice were severely impaired in object recognition memory (figure 1). 

Male adult Shank1+/− mice were impaired in object recognition memory as reflected by a complete lack of preference for the novel over the familiar object, suggesting that Shank1 may play a role in learning and memory (figure 2a), however this deficit was not observed in female mice or juvenile Shank1+/− mice. 
Of note, Shank2 +/− and Shank3 +/− mice, show weaker or absent phenotypes relative to homozygous knockout mice.

Both Shank1+/− and Shank1−/− mice showed normal social behavior (social preference and social recognition)
evidence.rdfs:label: Cognitive deficit in Shank1 deficient mice

evidence.dc:description: Scored 0 due to lack of consistency of the effects of Shank1 deficiency on repetitive behavior across assays and across studies. Silverman et al., 2011 (PMID: 20868654) did not observe genotype differences on repetitive behavior in Shank1 +/-, -/- and wild-type littermates.

Repetitive behaviors, including self-grooming, digging behavior, and marble burying, were assessed in Shank1−/− , Shank1+/− , and Shank1+/+ mice. The effect of social context on presence or absence of social odors in the cage bedding on the occurrence of repetitive behaviors was also assessed. Shank1+/- mice (but not Shank1-/- null mice) displayed elevated levels of self-grooming as adults, but not as juveniles. Digging behavior was not affected by genotype. In contrast, marble burying was strongly reduced in adult Shank1+/− and Shank1−/− mice across social contexts compared to Shank1+/+ littermates.
evidence.rdfs:label: Repetitive behaviors in Shank1+/− mice

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded to 1 because the mice studied are homozygous rather than heterozygous.

Shank1-/- mice exhibit reduced Homer protein levels, reduced dendritic spine size, and decreased basal synaptic transmission in the CA1 region of the hippocampus.

Synaptic transmission and plasticity phenotype altered in the model system are important cellular processes required for normal cognitive development in humans.
evidence.rdfs:label: Shank1-/- mice reduced dendritic spine and synaptic strength

evidence.dc:description: This variant escapes nonsense-mediated decay (NMD); truncating variants that escape NMD have also been reported in SHANK3 (Phelan-McDermid syndrome). Per ID/ASD GCEP, score capped at 2 points.
expression of c.3314del (p.Gly1105AlafsTer?) in 293T cells resulted in stable transcripts expression, indicating that this variant escapes NMD
